DefaultDialogue: Well now, we don't see as many travelers as we once did.\n\nBut if you seek safe harbor, you are welcome in Brightwood.
You are welcome here. Brightwood may not be as 'bright' as it once was, but it is still a bastion of light.\n\nThe territory's curse cannot penetrate the settlement walls.
I had hoped that if the Inquisitors performed such cruel deeds, it would be forgotten.\n\nBut Herbalist Lau believes this is actually why Brightwood is cursed.
The strangest thing happened to me earlier.\n\nEmbalmer Bankole hasn't spoken a word for decades, but he came to me as if it was just a normal thing.
There were of course legends and fables about such things way back when I was new here.\n\nThe earliest humans on Aeternum were beyond savage.
There were of course legends and fables about such things way back when I was new here.\n\nThe earliest humans on Aeternum were beyond savage.
At this point, I have no doubt about it - the heaviness that plagued Brightwood for centuries is gone.\n\nAnd we have you to thank for itâ€¦ only I still can't recall your name.
After all you've done for us, it occurs to me there might be a way to repay you.\n\nA legendary axe, wielded by the Inquisitors, we could actually reforge it.
Ah, {playerName}! Look at that - I remembered this time! The one who wields Executioner.\n\nYou're always welcome in Brightwood, though keep that axe hidden if you will. Bad memories, of course.
Well then, welcome to Brightwood, I suppose. \n\nMind your soul around these parts - they tend to get Lost.
Don't know what you've heard about Brightwood, stranger, but it may well be true.\n\nWe've been dug in here battling the soulless Lost for centuries.
It's true that the Inquisition in Brightwood ultimately failed, but they knew how to fight the Lost.\n\nThe more of their relics we can gather, the more we can bring to the fight.
Perhaps it is a good thing that we turn our attention away from the Inquisition.\n\nJusticiar Sobol believes we'll need to worry about Corruption soon enough.

As difficult as it may be to accept the truths you exposed, I think we made a difference in the fight against the Lost here.\n\nI've heard Weaver's Fen is still having their fair share of challenges as well.
I heard you eventually made your way out to the Fen!\n\nI've also heard the Lost there are even worse than they are here. I can't imagine.
Hi there! I'm actually quite new to Brightwood myself.\n\nThings got weird in Ebonscale, so I decided to take my chances here.
I trust you've heard at least some of the history of Brightwood?\n\nI only know a little myself, but it seems clear the territory is haunted in more ways than one.
So I guess we succeeded in dredging up the Head Cleric's memories.\n\nBut I have a feeling there's still more darkness in Brightwood's history.
I was right, you know. The atrocities committed by the Inquisitors were just the icing on the cake.\n\nI've also come to the conclusion that you and I - we have a lot in common.
I think maybe the Reaper had this Locus implanted in their wrist?\n\nAnd then, when they cut creatures down, it must've absorbed the azothâ€¦ like this? Huh. Wonder if I can get it to work again.
I see you, stranger, and I see your soul. \n\nStrong it may be, but is it strong enough?
Brightwood is no different than anywhere else on Aeternum.\n\nWe see the Lost as enemies, but we don't realize what terrible suffering they endure.
I know Justiciar Farrell pursues an edge against the Lost with a passion that borders on madness.\n\nI wonder if we might bring her relief with what we've learned.
I understand Justiciar Farrell was quite relieved to receive your gifts.\n\nI only hope we someday learn how we might bring the same relief to the Lost themselves.
You have ushered in a new dawn here in Brightwood.\n\nI wonder if you might like a fitting emblem - a Staff of Life - a very potent one?
With that staff in hand, you are the very thing, young one.\n\nHope Manifest, indeed.
It seems unfair that we spend decades here battling the Lost, only to now face a new threat.\n\nI hope the Corruption doesn't spread any further.
We've been waiting for the Corruption to spread here ever since Shattered Mountain erupted.\n\nSomehow, we've been lucky so far.
So now it seems we'll be defending Brightwood against two threats - the Lost and the Corrupted!\n\nNo one said it would be easy, did they?
Impressive! You are truly girded for war!\n\nBattle's Embrace will protect you from the worst of what the Corrupted or the Lost can throw at you.
Move along you, I won't go so far as to draw steel against you, but it doesn't mean I want to chit-chat.
Duty calls me to Brightwood, where strength is truly tested. I am at home here. We shall see if you have equal mettle.
Duty calls me to Brightwood, where strength is truly tested. I am at home here. We shall see if you have equal mettle.\n\n[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
Those books can't prepare you for Brightwood. No matter, as I'll enjoy picking over your corpse in due time.
You light bringers bore me. If your belief really worked, then why does the darkness remain here? Save your breath. I already know.
Ah, one who wanders without knowledge of their destination. How curious.
The quest to know and understand is our shared duty. How may I service you, fellow erudite?
The quest to know and understand is our shared duty.  Return when you understand more.\n\n[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
Oh this will be fascinating! A Marauder brute here in Brightwood. I look forward to learning from your failures.
Yes, come hither my senseless friend. Tell me again how belief in fairy tales helps to solve mankind's ills. I never tire of it.

Ah, a fellow ponderer of perpetual mysteries, and an accomplished one at that!

Yes, I know about you, {playerName}. You are here to face the trial for advancement to the rank of Scrivener?

[ Level 20 required for "Trial of the Scrivener"]
Ah, a fellow ponderer of perpetual mysteries, and an accomplished one at that!\n\nYes, I know about you, {playerName}. You are here to face the trial for advancement to the rank of Scrivener?

Mark my words, {playerName}! You will be famous for assisting in my experiment!

Imagine what we can accomplish by harvesting soul traces!

[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
Mark my words, {playerName}! You will be famous for assisting in my experiment!\n\nImagine what we can accomplish by harvesting soul traces!

Salutations, {playerName}. I think you know the tragic fate that befell Krockes.

Always exercise caution, a lesson we all must remember lest we share his fate.

[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
Salutations, {playerName}. I think you know the tragic fate that befell Krockes.\n\nAlways exercise caution, a lesson we all must remember lest we share his fate.
My child, having not chosen a path is still a choice. It's never too late to leave darkness for the light.
May the Spark carry you, my true believer. It will be my sacred honor to assist you.
May the Spark carry you, my true believer. It will be my sacred honor to assist you.\n\n[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
Well aren't you a strong-looking one! Not that it'll do you much good here in Brightwood. But then, choices do have consequences, and I'm afraid you chose unwisely, Marauder.
Oh my dear, so much rushing about, trying to learn everything. Such a pointless waste, when all we need is belief in the Spark.

The Spark is strong here in Brightwood. Beneath the darkness, there is always light.

The Spark is strong in you too, {playerName}. You are ready to face your trial and become a Templar, yes?

[ Level 20 required for "Trial of the Templar" Quest ]
The Spark is strong here in Brightwood. Beneath the darkness, there is always light.\n\nThe Spark is strong in you too, {playerName}. You are ready to face your trial and become a Templar, yes?

This business with Bremen Luca was unfortunate and doesn't exactly reflect well on the order.

Let's keep this quiet, shall we?

[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
This business with Bremen Luca was unfortunate and doesn't exactly reflect well on the order.\n\nLet's keep this quiet, shall we?

I heard the terrible news about Excubitor Luca. This is why I have chosen to refrain from family ties, or any attachments, really. 

The Spark is all the family I need.

[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
I heard the terrible news about Excubitor Luca. This is why I have chosen to refrain from family ties, or any attachments, really. \n\nThe Spark is all the family I need.
Oh dear, you startled me! The spooks and spirits of this town have got me on edge.\n\nWell, let me welcome you to the Weary Bones Lodge. We guarantee that our guests will rest in peace. Ha.
You there, you've seen the Corrupted forces pushing down from the north, have you not?\n\nEastburn Outpost in Great Cleave is now behind enemy lines, and I fear they are desperate.
Oh dear, you startled me! The spooks and spirits of this town have got me on edge.\n\nWell, let me welcome you to the Weary Bones Lodge. We guarantee that our guests will rest in peace. Ha.
Hello, I'm Master Fisher Park! Fishing and Alchemy are my trades.
Salutations. I'm Master Fisher Park! Fishing and Alchemy are my trades.
My research is going along well, thanks to you.
The moment I saw the Shattered Mountain erupting I knew it wouldn't be long.\n\nThe Corrupted have come to Brightwood in full force.
Ah, did you come from the settlement? Those fool Justiciars are so obsessed with the Lost, they have no idea.\n\nThe Corrupted have come to Brightwood, and they mean to stay.
I had thought to seek support from rangers in other territories, but I think you and I can handle this.\n\nI do the reconnaissance, you carry out the assault.
Master Smith McCoy was the Lead Artificer in Great Cleave for many years.\n\nIf he is making weapons for the Corrupted, then he has betrayed us.
I will remain and keep an eye on the Corrupted operations here.\n\nThough I suspect it will be some time before their supply lines are back in order, thanks to you.
They really should advertise the beauty of Greyvale. There is something marvelous about the ancient trees and the sparkling water. \n\nDon't you find all this nature inspiring?
Have you seen, really seen the landscape of Greyvale? The light falling through the leaves, or dancing across the lakes. \n\nOh, if only I had time to paint everything here!
Thereâ€™s something to be said about the energy in moving water, the way it draws your eye and catches it. The power that just leaps off the canvas and fills a room.
Waterfalls are thrilling indeed, but I also like to paint more tranquil landscapes. \n\nThereâ€™s nothing quite as soothing at staring at a placid lake, don't you agree? Itâ€™s almost magical.
Thanks to your help, my name shall be known in every household in Aeternum. \n\nMy paintings shall grace the walls of everyone who longs for a slice of nature to call their own.
Trees live for so long, and experience so much.  I wish I could know what they know.
Do you sense it, traveler? The force of life rides on the breeze from the south - the only vibrant flora remaining in these dead lands.\n\nIf you are headed that way, I could use a favor.
Ach! I am so sorry - I do not mean to be rude, but these leaves... they are too bitter.\n\nI will only gag if I attempt to consume such a brew. I will need something to sweeten my special tea.
While you were away, I took the time to study these leaves more closely, and I discovered an unfortunate truth.\n\nThe tea of the Angry Earth is more complex than I thought.
To have defeated the Angry Earth Shamans in the Verdant Cavern, you are clearly a formidable warrior.\n\nKnowing that, I have one more favor to ask.
Begone, human.  As I resume my place among the Angry Earth, I cannot guarantee your safety.\n\nYour generosity, however, we will remember, for all time.
If you're headed into Greyvale, I'd offer you one piece of advice.\n\nDon't feed the bears! Especially not with your own flesh and blood.
Say there, are you headed across the river, into Greyvale?\n\nThat's bear territory. I know that firsthand, because for me, it was also my home.
If I'm being completely honest, though, I really don't know what I'm supposed to do.\n\nWith Susan gone, and the bears turned on me, I don't have anywhere else to go.
Still working up the nerve. This is harder than I thought.\n\nIt's funny, those bears are the only family I've ever known - not sure if I'll ever feel completely comfortable with them, though.
If you're looking for the Brightwood settlement, it's to the north.\n\nNothing to the south, except for lost love... and remorse.
It may seem hard to believe, but this was once one of the safest and liveliest parts of Brightwood.\n\nAll that remains now are my memories, very sad ones. And now, even those are starting to fade.
I'm sorry. This is no good. These keepsakes you recovered for me, they were supposed to make me sad.\n\nAt this point, I've run out of hope, and frankly, I'd rather just be done with it.
Reading this is like visiting an old friend - it's veryâ€¦ emotional. \n\nBut rather than making me sad, it's making me angry. You see, when the truth came out, everyone in town turned on me.
Well, it just goes to show, life is only for those bold and courageous enough to truly live it.\n\nPastor Walsham was always so damn conflicted. I think maybe now, I can start over.
Salutations, {playerName}. I think you know the tragic fate that befell Krockes.\n\nAlways exercise caution, a lesson we all must remember lest we share his fate.

Salutations, {playerName}. I think you know the tragic fate that befell Krockes.

Always exercise caution, a lesson we all must remember lest we share his fate.

[ Level 24 required for Brightwood faction missions ]
